results.title: Stolen Valor: The U.S. Volunteers in Ukraine Who Lie, Waste and Bicker
results.abstract: People who would not be allowed anywhere near the battlefield in a U.S.-led war are active on the Ukrainian front, with ready access to American weapons.

media.caption: Axel Vilhelmsen trained Ukrainian soldiers last year as part of the Mozart Group, which two former Marines established to help Ukraine. It disbanded after one founder sued the other, alleging theft and harassment.

results.title: Expelling Rahul Gandhi From Parliament, Modi Allies Thwart a Top Rival

results.adx_keywords: Elderly;Content Type: Service;Anesthesia and Anesthetics;Tests (Medical);Surgery and Surgeons;Doctors;Volunteers and Community Service;Transportation
results.title: You May Need That Procedure. But Do You Really Need an Escort?
results.abstract: Following even basic screenings and operations, patients often must arrange for someone to deliver them home. For older people, it can be a tall order.

media.caption: Robert Lewinger, a retired lawyer who lives alone, can’t schedule any of the surgical procedures he needs unless he supplies the name and phone number of the person taking him home afterward. “It shouldn’t be so hard,” he said.
media.copyright: Janice Chung for The New York Times

results.title: Think Getting Into College Is Hard? Try Applying for These Gyms.
results.abstract: A new crop of luxury gyms requires referrals, interviews and even, in some cases, medical evaluations. And that’s before paying a monthly fee of up to $2,750.

media.caption: Ghost, a gym in Williamsburg, is part of a new crop of luxury fitness centers requiring an extensive application process. “If you’re making widgets in Akron, Ohio, they may not want you,” said the founder of another gym.

results.adx_keywords: your-feed-science;Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Vaccination and Immunization;Elderly;Immune System;Food and Drug Administration
results.title: Should You Get Another Covid Booster?
results.abstract: Britain and Canada have authorized another round of booster shots for older and immunocompromised citizens. So far, U.S. officials haven’t followed suit.

media.caption: A woman receiving a fourth shot in September in Phoenix. While a Covid infection can be a matter of inconvenience for some, it can spell severe disease, hospitalization and death for older adults and immunocompromised people.
media.copyright: Ash Ponders for The New York Times
